Comes from: from ethylene and ethanol in industrial processes or naturally found in foods due to fermentation.
In Embodiment:
No.
We tend to use fatty acids from plant-based oils and vegan sources.

It's also an ingredient found in hair straightening products -> https://patents.google.com/patent/US6517822B1/en. Whereas, while we're not against hair straighterns, we prefer to enhance the hair rather than change it.
Extraction method: While propionic is an organic compound and naturally found in nature from the fermentation of sugars, its extraction is usually done by industrial means that are non-biological. https://sciencing.com/facts-6790531-meaning-thermal-processing-.html
History:
In 1844, Johann Gottlieb, discovered propionic acid. As soon as in 1879, the Fitz created the equation of the fermenation of lactic acid found in milk, into acetic acid and propionic acid.

It has been used as a good preservative in foods and is thus considered safe for consumption.

Comes from: It's typically not found in oils as it's a product of bacterial fermentation of carbohydrates and proteins.
Used in: food as an additive or enhancer

Comes from:
It can be found naturally in a variety of sources, including certain plants, animal fats, and dairy products.

It can be found in some plants such as valerian (Valeriana officinalis), a flowering plant native to Europe and Asia, from which valeric acid derives its name.

In small amounts, you'll find it in peanut oil, coconut oil and palm kernel oil.
Used in: Medical uses, gut health and anti-microbial capabilities.

it plant and animal sources, such as coconut oil, palm kernel oil, nutmeg, milk and butterfat.
Used in: It is used in the production of soaps, detergents, and other personal care products, as well as in the food industry as a flavoring agent and preservative. Has medical benefits, anti-microbial properties and anti-inflammatory capabilities

Comes from: Stearic acid comes from animal fats and vegetable oils. +https://www.sciencedirect.com/book/9780128104606/handbook-of-pharmaceutical-wet-granulation
Used in: It's used in supplements, cosmetics, soaps, detergents and candle waxes. +https://draxe.com/nutrition/what-is-stearic-acid/.
Frizz taming: Stearic acid is known to smooth the cuticles of the hair and help tame frizz with regular use.
Introduction: Like us, you may have heard about Stearic acid as it's one of the most common fatty acids there are. Despite associating it with olive oil and plant based origins, we were suprised to find it's also found in animals fats too. Seeing as we humans are made of fats and fats are not bad (just excessive fat in our bodies is unhealthy for us), it is reasonable to believe it would also be beneficial on our hair and skin.
Breakage: It has been shown to be very effective of increasing hair strength with regular use. ::https://fashionandtextiles.springeropen.com/articles/10.1186/s40691-021-00282-5/tables/14

Hair shine: Linoleic acid can make the hair shine by smoothing the hair fibers.
Frizz taming: Linoleic acid is known to smooth the cuticles of the hair and help tame frizz with regular use.

Hair shine: Oleic improves hair shine with regular use over time.
Frizz taming: Oleic acid can help tame frizz and flyaways by smoothing the cuticles of the hair fiber. One [paper](#resources) saw how it transformed damaged hair with only 21 days of regular use.
Breakage: It has been shown to maintain the strength of hair when used as a conditioner if you shampoo your hair as shampooing itself is damaging. However, it's not as effective as other oils such as linoleic acid, stearic acid and palmitic acid.
